You are trying to figure why there are so many dead deer in one spot, and then you trace a line up the mountain - leaves and such are scattered all the way up...to a grove. constituent: hades, crown, sun, day, six

Since no one knows precisely when this part of the cosmos was finished, we may imagine it as the crowning deed of day six of the creation.
koohiiStory1: The beast of hades one day will wear a crown, and the number of the beast is 666.
koohiiStory2: In Hades you have to work six days a week before crowning it with something vaguely resembling a weekend. Oh wait, that´s Japan.

constituent: domburi, well, drop

koohiiStory2: How many brains does it take to run the capital suburbs?

constituent: fist, quarter, hand

koohiiStory2: Quarter, hand: If you have a roll of quarters in your hand, your fist will deliver a much more effective punch.

constituent: large hill, maestro, ten, needle

The full kanji for the City Walls primitive is city walls (#2180). Beyonce went for an invigorating walk up a large hill on a summer´s afternoon. Since the grass was so lush and cool, she took off her sandals and immediately stepped on a used hypodermic needle. 岐阜県　ぎふけん Gifu Prefecture.

constituent: interrogative, sword, dagger, two, city walls

koohiiStory2: Interrogation at the city walls: "Any weapons, question mark." "Just a blade." "Why the two scratches on the blade, question mark." "To remind me that I cut off my other ear too, exclamation mark (exclamation (#2680)).".
words: 旦那(だんな): master (of house), husband (informal)

constituent: stationery, bamboo, float, fiesta, float*, fiesta2

Until such time as typesetting fonts make the adjustment, only the older form has been approved. Here we have opted for the simpler, avant garde drawing.

koohiiStory2: The two fiestas communicated to each other on their respective floats by using bamboo stationery.

constituent: glossary, broken broom, mutual, crown, fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood, broom*
heisigStory: The top primitive of this character is actually an old form of broom. The remaining elements are: crown . . . fruit.

koohiiStory2: I was having mutual difficulties in my relationship. She was always the one wearing the crown and I was the one picking the fruit. In order to fix the problem I checked the glossary for "mutual difficulties" but found nothing. I guess we´re going to have to mutually end our relationship.
words: 語彙(ごい): vocabulary, glossary

heisigStory: You have seen those scratch'n'sniff advertisements for perfumes. This one is for a mouthwash that replaces one stinking oder with another.
koohiiStory1: Your mouth stinks: you need to sniff your breath.
koohiiStory2: You open your mouth and gasp for air, 1 sniff of that stinking chihuahua is too much. *Edited thecite's to reflect the keyword in the supplement.

heisigStory: People who try to sound literary often end up butchering the language. Here we see a meeting of butchers whose mouths are producing the metaphors.
koohiiStory1: Metaphorically speaking, all the equipment in your mouth is basically just a meeting of butchers, designed to pulverize whatever meat you put in there.
koohiiStory2: Metaphor: A good metaphor flows from the mouth like the meeting of flesh and saber, smoothly piercing the listener with its meaning. But a bad metaphor is like when you barely nick the flesh and only spill two drops of blood or when your saber doesn't penetrate at all but rather bends into a くく shape when you whack the flesh. (Note: This story incorporates both the traditional form of the kanji (口＋兪) and the simplified form (口＋俞)) .

heisigStory: The words of this obituary work like a magic wand, conjuring up the desceased.
koohiiStory1: Obituary. As a famous man lay dying, the media were already preparing the words of his obituary until a magician, with a wave of his wand, restored the man back to health.
koohiiStory2: In the Harry Potter world, obituary's are magical. If you wave your wand over them you can hear the person's last words. Creepy!

heisigStory: The key word refers to kanji that are written in full, squared form, as opposed to cursive writing which is more flowing andabbreviates some of the strokes. Here block letters are pictured as tidy rows of trees that are all the same size and can be read easily by all, whatever calligraphic skills they possess.
koohiiStory1: Block letters (as opposed to cursive) are rigid and lifeless like wood; they're all the same size so that all can read them.
koohiiStory2: all the hiragana are in "block letters" on wooden blocks, like children's toys.

heisigStory: The harmoney of "a place for everything and everything in its place" is applied here to the orderliness of all the words one speaks.
koohiiStory1: To have orderliness, your words must be in all the right places.
koohiiStory2: 起立(きりつ)！ Hearing these words, all the students immediately stand at attention. The orderliness of classes in Japan is incredible.

koohiiStory1: You weld metal in the knowledge that it will harden again.
koohiiStory2: By welding metal and then subjecting it to refrigeration, it will become very hard by the process known as annealing.

koohiiStory1: A selfish person doesn't care about the next person's heart, only their own.
koohiiStory2: Selfish lover breaks your heart and moves on to the next lover. (And yawns with a heart of ice at your suffering).

koohiiStory1: My mind found the tool disquieting.
koohiiStory2: Its disquieting to my state of mind when tools are arranged messily.

koohiiStory1: My mind hankers for sunrise over the capital.
koohiiStory2: I'm in a state of mind where I hanker to see the sun over the capital for some nice scenery for a change (no more rain!)

heisigStory: The sense of this key word is to pull or jerk, as in opening a door or making "ramen" noodles. Its elements: fingers . . . vase.
koohiiStory1: He quickly yanked his fingers out of the vase. Maybe no one noticed the attempt to steal the cookies...
koohiiStory2: He yanked his finger out of the vase upon discovering it had a venus fly trap in it.
kunYomi: くだ.く、 ひし.ぐ、 らっ.する

heisigStory: Person . . . soil . . . compass . . . taskmaster. You may, of course, take the character for emulate from the previous frame as the basis for this kanji, adding to it only the element for soil.
koohiiStory1: He showed his arrogance as he poured dirt on those who tried to emulate him.
koohiiStory2: Your arrogance has soiled your attempt to emulate such an honorable effort.

heisigStory: Wooden leg . . . religion. The key word refers to a trail of footprints or tracks left behind.
koohiiStory1: A trail of destruction is left by pirates and religion invaders.
koohiiStory2: The followers of the crazy satanic religion are following the footprints of the escaped human sacrifices who fled from the altar.

heisigStory: The key word should be taken to mean minute, detailed, or nuanced. Its primitive elements are: thread . . . doth.
koohiiStory1: THREAD, DOTH. fine THREADS DOTH make fine cloth. Think of a Shakespearean character stating this to someone else. Picture fine threads on one side of the picture and an aftershot of a fine cloth.
koohiiStory2: fine: If the thread doth fit through the eye of the needle, it is fine thread indeed.

heisigStory: The holed gem to which this kanji refers is a flat, circular object of about a foot in length, made of stone or glass and having a large hole in the middle. It's elements: ketchup . . . ball.
koohiiStory1: Even more valuable and perfect (完璧) than a holed gem is a delicious meatball (ball = たま = 玉) with ketchup. Yum!
koohiiStory2: It's a little known fact that ketchup is highly corrosive and is used to cut holes into gemstones so they can be put onto chains. This kanji shows a piece of Jade with a blob of ketchup on the top eating a hole through it.

heisigStory: Of the many and widely different meanings of this kanji, we select the verbal meaning of clasp, which fits in well with its primitive elements: tenacious . . . hand.
koohiiStory1: When you clasp something you tenaciously 執 hold on to it with your hand 手, te. 真摯、しんし, sincerity, earnestness.
koohiiStory2: This kanji shows Santa Claus (refer to frame tenacious (#1506)) clasping the reins of his deers with his hands, holding onto dear life as he almost falls off his carriage.

koohiiStory1: Whatever you covet at the moment (now), can be bought with money. Well, _almost_ anything....
koohiiStory2: One begins one's life coveting money. One ends one's life coveting time -- those precious seconds ticking away on the clock. Remember to always put time over money (in this kanji and in life).

koohiiStory1: Shudder. If chestnut trees were sentient, shudder would be their state of mind as the tree shaker approaches. Note: Tree shakers are used commercially to harvest nuts and cider apples. A tree shaker makes a tree shudder causing all the ripe chestnuts to fall.
koohiiStory2: shudder: You’re in the state of mind of shuddering with fear when the chestnut tree is falling over towards you.
kunYomi: おそ.れる、 おのの.く、 ふる.える

koohiiStory1: The bitter taste was so awful that I put whole bundle of spice in my mouth to get rid of it.
koohiiStory2: I'm rather bitter that someone stole my spice bundle.

koohiiStory1: His sickness caused numerous carbuncles, which when emptied by the doctors also emptied his piggy bank.
koohiiStory2: The witches piggy bank was cursed with a spell causing any thief who stole it's contents to fall ill. The illness would result in the victim being covered from head to toe in a mass of carbuncles. Crime doesn't pay!

koohiiStory1: The scaredy-cat soldier puts his dog tags in his mouth and suckles them nervously. It sounds like he's a suckling infant.
koohiiStory2: suckle: this mother had heptuplets. Wow! But she had to put dog tags on the mouths of her babies to keep track of which ones had been suckled.

heisigStory:
Learning this character will take a little doing. Before we start, it is a good idea to keep the key word distinct from melancholy (Frame 663), with which it combines to create the psychological condition of depression (a metaphor based on the hollow or sinking of the material depression we met in Frame 1421).
The picture of gloom begins with a small grove of trees, under which we see a crown made out of used tin cans. Next (the lower half of the kanji) we find a combination that appears only a few times in modern characters and only once in those treated in the volumes of Remembering the Kanji. It is composed of a shovel with a sheaf dotted with small drops on all sides. Think of it as a large scoop shovel attached to the front of a bulldozer, whose driver is singing: ♪ "Bulldozing in the sheaves, bulldozing in the sheaves..." ♪ The drops represent the chaff flying about as the sheaves are tossed about by the heavy machinery.
There is someone sitting on the ground alongside, watching as the machinery makes its way around the neighboring farmland - and it's you, wearing your tin-can crown. You feel overwhelmed by the impending doom as the invasion of agro-business draws closer and closer to the grove, the only patch of woods that remains of what once was a vast forest. The whole scene represents a re-shaping of the natural environment that brings the heavy weight of gloom down upon you.
A bit much, perhaps, but there are enough elements to allow for any number of other combinations.
koohiiStory1: The pixie, wearing a tin can crown, watches from the middle of the grove, the sparkling villain approach. She sits down in gloom wondering if she belongs amongst the trees, for she has never seen such a beautiful shape.
koohiiStory2: The context of gloom here refers to an environmental disaster that humans make. The story begins at a GROVE with TIN CANS shaped like CROWNS which are really soda cans. They belonged to workers who bulldozes (or SHOVELS) lots and lots of SHEAVES with DROPS of its pieces. Afar, a boy is SITTING while watching the workers reSHAPING the environment. His face now has a very gloomy expression.
kunYomi: うっ.する、 しげ.る、 ふさ.ぐ

koohiiStory1: The sheep had his coat shaven in the winter and a sign of th cow branded on him. How humiliating.
koohiiStory2: [+melchan] The sheep was humiliated by being branded with the sign of the cow (which is a major insult to anyone, even sheep) and tries to cover it up with it's wool.
kunYomi: すすめ.る、 はじ.る、 は.ずかしい
